SEYMOUR KETY, 84, LEADER IN BIOLOGICAL PSYCHIATRY 

  
 (ATTN: Mass., Pa., Md.)  (ART ADV: Photo NYT26 is being sent to NYT photo clients.
Nonsubscribers can purchase one-time rights by calling 888-603-1036
or 888-346-9867.) 
 By WOLFGANG SAXON   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Dr. Seymour S. Kety, a major figure in the field of biological
psychiatry whose contributions revolutionized the study of
schizophrenia and other major mental illnesses and yielded novel
methods for studying the human brain at work, died on Thursday at
his home in Westwood, Mass. He was 84.

   In giving him its 1999 Award for Special Achievement in Medical
Science, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation cited Kety's
discovery, in the late 1940s and early '50s, of the first
quantitative technique for measuring blood flow in the living
brain, a method that eventually led to the development of modern
technologies like PET scanning.

   The foundation also recognized Kety for his work on
schizophrenia, the first to provide strong evidence that the
illness ran in families, an indication that heredity played a
significant role. The studies, which used Danish national birth
registries to track the transmission of the illness in people
separated at birth from their biological families, helped overturn
the then-prevailing wisdom that schizophrenia was caused by bad
parenting.

   Schizophrenia is not entirely genetic; environmental stressors,
as yet not completely understood, appear to trigger the illness in
those with a genetic vulnerability.

   Kety's studies also laid the groundwork for efforts to identify
specific genes that might predispose a person to develop the
disease, efforts that continue to this day.

   ``We found that 10 percent of the biological relatives of
schizophrenic adoptees have the disorder themselves,'' Kety told an
interviewer upon receiving the Lasker Award, ``a fivefold higher
prevalence than exists in the general population.''

   As the first scientific director of the new National Institute
of Mental Health in the early 1950s, Kety also helped shift the
direction of psychiatric research, putting much greater emphasis on
the biological bases of mental illness.

   At the time, psychoanalysis dominated most academic psychiatry
departments, but Kety ``believed that there were physiological and
chemical problems that lay behind mental disease,'' said Dr. Louis
Sokoloff, chief of the laboratory of cerebral metabolism at the
mental health institute, who worked with Kety as a postdoctoral
student at the University of Pennsylvania.

   In bestowing its award, the Lasker Foundation noted that Kety's
``visionary leadership in mental health,'' helped usher
``psychiatry into the molecular age.''

   At the time of his death, Kety (pronounced KET-ty) was an
emeritus professor of neuroscience at the Harvard Medical School,
having retired in 1983 after 15 years, and until three years ago he
was senior psychobiologist at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass.

   Seymour Solomon Kety was born in Philadelphia. He graduated Phi
Beta Kappa in 1936 from the University of Pennsylvania, where he
received his M.D. in 1940. He entered Harvard Medical School as a
National Research Council fellow in 1942.

   Kety taught and conducted research at Penn before becoming
scientific director at the institute. As a researcher in
physiology, he made many significant contributions to the field,
including a seminal 1951 paper on the mechanisms of gas exchange
between blood and the body tissues.

   Soon after arriving at the mental health institute, Sokoloff
said, Kety found himself under pressure from his colleagues to
undergo psychoanalysis _ a treatment considered de rigueur for
practicing psychiatrists at the time.

   Kety, Sokoloff said, ``didn't have much interest in
psychoanalysis, but they kept hounding him, and they finally said
the institute would pay for it.''

   That evening, Sokoloff continued, Kety remarked to his wife,
Josephine, that maybe he should take advantage of the institute's
offer.

   ``Well, suppose they offered you a free appendectomy,'' Sokoloff
said his wife replied, ``would you take that?''

   In the mid-1960s, Kety briefly left the mental health institute
to become chairman of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University. But
clinical practice was not his first love, Sokoloff said, and he
soon returned to the institute and to basic research.

   In 1967, he joined the psychiatry faculty at Harvard, becoming
director of the psychiatric research laboratory at Massachusetts
General Hospital, where he remained until 1977, when he accepted a
similar position at the Mailman Research Center at McLean.

   Survivors include his wife of 60 years, Dr. Josephine Gross
Kety; a son, Lawrence; a daughter, Roberta; and two grandchildren.
